The same organisers of the "Day of Anger" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest in front of the presidential [[Heliopolis Palace]] on 4 February, which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. The same organisers of the "Day of Anger" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest all over Egypt on 4 February, which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February their deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as many of the protesters again spent the night in Tahrir Square. Pro-government protesters were also active and small-scale clashes happened in the early hours.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
